sentences.sentence: Friday's announcement that the Liberals and NDP have reached a pharmacare funding deal signals that the government is determined(https://financialpost.com/pmn/business-pmn/trudeau-liberals-ndp-reach-deal-on-national-drug-coverage-plan) to introduce legislation that will leave many Canadians with significantly diminished drug coverage.A single-payer system is a complicated and costly proposition.

While the details of the proposed plan have yet to be revealed, and initial reports have only identified limited coverage for specific drugs in the short term, it is said to establish a framework for a national pharmacare program, and one that NDP Leader Jagmeet Sign has stated "clearly points to (a) single payer" system.A report(https://www.pbo-dpb.ca/en/publications/RP-2324-016-S--cost-estimate-single-payer-universal-drug-plan--estimation-couts-un-regime-assurance-medicaments-universel-payeur-unique) last fall from the Parliamentary Budget Officer estimated that total drug expenditures under a comprehensive, single-payer plan would be $33.2 billion in its first full fiscal year of implementation, rising to $38.9 billion within three years.

That is quite the price tag for a government that touts fiscal responsibility as a priority.What's worse is that despite the hefty cost, single-payer pharmacare would actually leave most Canadians worse off.

The current reality is that the majority of Canadians are covered by employer-sponsored drug insurance plans(https://www150.statcan.gc.ca/n1/daily-quotidien/240110/dq240110a-eng.htm) that allow them to benefit from faster access to more medicines.

Canadians on public plans wait more than two years(https://www.conferenceboard.ca/product/access-and-time-to-patient-jan2024/) to access new medicines, compared to just 226 days(https://iedm.org/the-dangers-of-a-pan-canadian-drug-insurance-program/ ) for those with private coverage.

Canadians on private plans have access to 45 per cent(https://phrma.org/-/media/Project/PhRMA/PhRMA-Org/PhRMA-Refresh/Report-PDFs/A-C/2023-04-20-PhRMA-Global-Access-to-New-Medicines-Report-FINAL-1.pdf) of new drugs launched globally, and while that number may seem underwhelming, it's two and a half times the 18 per cent that are available on public plans.The questions Canadians should be asking themselves are: "Do I want to wait more than three times longer for fewer than half the drugs I currently have access to?"
And "Is the upheaval of switching over from a mixed drug system to a single-payer plan with universal coverage proportionate to the problem we face?"

Analysis(https://www.conferenceboard.ca/in-fact/understanding-the-gap/) by the Conference Board of Canada found that fully 97.2 per cent of Canadians are eligible for some form of prescription drug coverage.
The uninsured gap is therefore just 2.8 per cent.

It does not make sense to completely trash a system most Canadians are happy with in order to close such a small gap - though it clearly should be closed.In Budget 2023, Ottawa announced the Canadian Dental Care Plan(https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/news/2023/12/the-canadian-dental-care-plan.html) to help up to nine million uninsured Canadians get access to dental care, declaring it was "not intended to be a replacement for existing dental benefits offered through employer/pension-sponsored or private plans" but rather a program to "fill existing gaps in coverage and complement existing provincial and territorial dental programs.

"Except for political considerations, it is unclear why the government would not adopt a similar approach to fill the significantly smaller, uninsured gap for drug coverage, rather than choose just a few drugs that it will now cover for people who, in the great majority, already have them covered.
Surely these resources could be better directed.How much resilience do Europe and Russia have left?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/william-watson-how-much-resilience-do-europe-and-russia-have-left)COP28 psychodrama vs. WTO grunt work(https://financialpost.com/opinion/tale-two-confabs-cop28-psychodrama-wto-grunt-work)How to make free people smarter?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/libertarians-dilemma-how-make-free-people-smarter)We can only hope that as legislation makes its way through parliamentary and public discussion, the government will take a more sensible approach that actually improves coverage and gives all Canadians faster access to more of the life-saving and life-improving medicines they need.Financial PostKathy Megyery, senior vice-president at the Canadian Chamber of Commerce, is policy lead for life sciences and health innovation.

Pascal Chan, also at the Chamber, is senior director, transportation, infrastructure &; construction.Bookmark our website and support our journalism: Don't miss the business news you need to know - add financialpost.com(https://financialpost.com/ ) to your bookmarks and sign up for our newsletters here(https://financialpost.com/newsletters/ ).
